intro: Amphithalea minima, commonly known as the dwarf sandmat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its small, fleshy leaves and clusters of tiny, pinkish-white flowers. The plant thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Its botanical features include a sprawling growth habit and the ability to produce achenes as its reproductive structures. Amphithalea minima is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
